bestBHT.bht: Jesus, in responding to his adversary, makes it clear that one cannot serve both Satan and God. Although the exact words Get thee behind me, Satan are not included, their absence suggests that Jesus recognizes his foe and chooses to obey God. This underscores the importance of wholehearted devotion to God alone, as stated in Deuteronomy 6:13, where the fear of God encompasses both internal and external worship.

Henry Alford: If the words 'Get thee behind me, Satan' had been here, as in A.V., St. Luke could hardly have left the record as it stands.
This being the first direct recognition by our Lord of His foe, after which, and in obedience to which command, he departs from Him.
In obedience to which command, he departs from Him.
Philip Schaff: Luke 4:8. The words: ‘Get thee behind me, Satan,’ should be omitted.
Archibald T. Robertson: Jesus clearly perceived that one could not worship both Satan and God. He had to choose whom he would serve.
Luke does not give the words, 'Get thee hence, Satan,' for he has another temptation to narrate.
John Gill: Jesus answered and said unto him,.... The following words, with indignation at him, and detestation of his proposals: get thee behind me, Satan...
For it is written, thou shalt worship the Lord thy God, and him only shalt thou serve.
...the fear of God being often, in Scripture, put for the whole worship of God, both internal and external.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus, in Luke 4:8, addresses his adversary, making it clear that one cannot serve both Satan and God. He firmly states, Get thee behind me, Satan, asserting his allegiance to the Lord. Luke does not provide these exact words, but the absence of the phrase suggests that the focus is on Jesus recognizing his foe and choosing to obey God. The Scripture reminds us that true worship is directed solely towards God, as stated in Deuteronomy 6:13. The fear of God encompasses both internal and external worship, emphasizing the importance of wholehearted devotion to God alone.

Jesus, responding to his adversary in Luke 4:8, affirms that one cannot serve both Satan and God, commanding him to depart. Although the exact words Get thee behind me, Satan are not included, their absence suggests that the focus is on Jesus acknowledging his opponent and choosing obedience to God. This highlights the significance of wholehearted devotion to God alone, as emphasized in Deuteronomy 6:13, where the fear of God encompasses both internal and external worship.

Jesus, in Luke 4:8, addresses his adversary, making it clear that one cannot serve both Satan and God. He firmly states, Get thee behind me, Satan, asserting his allegiance to the Lord. Luke does not provide these exact words, but the absence of the phrase suggests that the focus is on Jesus recognizing his foe and choosing to obey God. The Scripture reminds us that true worship is directed solely towards God, as stated in Deuteronomy 6:13. The fear of God encompasses both internal and external worship, emphasizing the importance of wholehearted devotion to God alone.

Jesus, in addressing his adversary, firmly declares, Get thee behind me, Satan, indicating his loyalty to God. Although these exact words are not recorded in Luke 4:8, their absence implies Jesus' recognition of his foe and commitment to obey God. The passage underscores the exclusive nature of true worship, as expressed in Deuteronomy 6:13. The fear of God extends beyond external acts to encompass internal devotion. This highlights the significance of wholehearted dedication solely to God.
